Michigan Initial Health & Safety Training Module B
Section 1: Child Development

Developmental Monitoring & Screening

Let’s discuss some aspects of developmental monitoring and screening.

  • WHAT Is It?

    Developmental monitoring is observing how a child grows and changes over time and whether he meets the typical developmental milestones. This can be done by parents, grandparents, child care providers, and others that are involved with the child on a regular basis.

    Developmental screening or assessment takes a closer look at the child’s development using a formalized tool. This is usually done by a physician or trained experts in the early intervention field.

  • WHEN are Monitoring and Screening Done?

    Monitoring is an ongoing process. There is material available to help families and providers know the typical developmental milestones for each age. Those will be discussed in further slides.

    The American Academy of Pediatricians (AAP) has established recommendations on when children should have formal screenings completed. It recommends ages 9 months, 18 months, and 30 months. AAP also states that any time a physician has a concern they should do a screening. AAP also recommends specific autism screening is done on each child when they reach 18 and 24 months. They also add that additional autism screenings should be done if concerns are noted.

  • WHY?

    Unfortunately, the majority of developmental delays are not identified until school entry. This means that valuable time was lost. The connections in a child’s brain are the most adaptive in the first 3 years of life. Therefore, the earlier developmental delays are detected, and intervention has begun, the greater the chance a young child has of achieving his highest potential.
